intro: Ageratina cuzcoensis, commonly known as the Cuzco blueweed, is a flowering plant native to the high-altitude regions of the Andes in South America. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows in rocky or dry habitats, showcasing adaptations to harsh, high-altitude environments. Its blue to purple flower heads are composed of numerous tiny florets, and it produces small, hairy fruits. Ageratina cuzcoensis is often found in cloud forests and is valued for its ornamental appeal and ecological role in its native habitat.
